Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2009 11:41PM geysermom wrote: MattsMom, I would ask a lymphedema PT or I can ask mine and PM you.  I see a PT at a lymphedema clinic for cords under both arms (no sign of lymphedema at this point).  I am also a motorclycle rider both as a passenger and now have my own bike.  I agree with Cheryl that a bike with an upright sitting position would be best.  Having weight on your arm all of the time or leaning forward could increase the swelling.  I didn't get my own bike until last year and picked the upright type motorcycle because it just felt more natural to me.  Is your lymphedema in both arms?  For motorcycle riding it would be more difficult if it is in you right arm since that hand needs to be on the throttle all of the time (kind of like the gas pedal on a car).  If it's on the left, you only use that hand to shift and once you are an accomplished rider you can actually remove that hand from the hand grip and move it around from time to time to prevent the swelling. Julie
Posts.Title: Motorcycles MattsMom t9jorda
Just diagnosed - what should we look for in a doctor? Snowflake70 LindaYO

Posts.Content: May 16, 2009 07:31PM geysermom wrote: Lursa, My story is similar although I did not progress quite as far as you did with the painkillers.  I did lose my job and my husband left (although that was really a blessing for me since he was abusive).  My kids had very little contact with me for almost 5 years since they went with their father and he convinced them I was obviously in a gutter somewhere (all while he took me to court repeatedly for more and more child support since I have always made signigicantly more money than he has).  I even made more money than him when I was on unemployment! I had PBM four weeks ago and my breast surgeon is well aware of my painkiller problem.  To tell you the truth, I have had a total of 4 surgeries in the past 18 months and have informed the surgeon each time that painkillers and I have a "history".  The two surgeons who have done my four surgeries have never withheld pain medication when I really needed it.  They both reassured me repeatedly when I had complications (from two of the surgeries) that warranted continued pain medication use long after what would have been customary.  I kept questioning it since I was worried about my history and they kept telling me that given what I was going through I really did need to continue with the pain medication. In my opinion, as an RN with 18 years experience, I can't see why the anesthesiologist needs to know unless you are worried that the preop medication dose may not be enough for you to realize any benefit.  Otherwise, the anesthesiologist specializes in making you sleep and the dosages for accomplishing that are tailored to the response of each patient and vary enough that they don't look at you, determine a dose and then forget about making any adjustments.  Remember also, if you do tell the anesthesiologist, you are probably not going to have a lot of contact with him (or her) in the future so it's not that big of deal. In my career I have run across a few surgeons who have been unreasonably stingy with pain medication so I encourage you to openly discuss this issue with your surgeon and ask how they feel about having to give you more medication because of your tolerance.  Their reaction to your "revelation" will tell you a lot.  I think being honest up front will save you from having your surgeon react badly and decide that he or she will not even consider prescribing the amount of medication you actually need. I am now very happily remarried to a very wonderful man who has been extraordinarily supportive during all of my surgeries and recoveries.  My DH is well aware of my history and helps me determine if I need a pain pill or if another intervention might help me just as much.  He also has assured me repeatedly that taking a pain pill was ok when I really needed it.  On a happier, life goes on note, my two children, now 22 and 24 just spent spring break with us and both sent me flowers and called on Mother's Day! You didn't say if your life was better now and if you have contact with your children.  I really hope so since going through this surgery is difficult and having a good support network (whatever that looks like) is so helpful. Good luck to you and I am sending postive thoughts and prayers your way. Julie P.S.  I didn't go to rehab since I didn't have insurance after losing my job and weaned myself off of narcotics completely on my own.  It was the most difficult thing I have ever done in my life and I ended up in the ED twice as well.
Posts.Title: To tell or not. Need Advice Lursa5 nancypat

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2009 03:19PM geysermom wrote: HelloFromCT, I had PBM for ADH and many other types of abnormal breast tissue (none cancer).  The recomendation after my last mammo was for 7 core needle biopsies and after multiple previous biopsies and a lumpectomy (for ADH) I decided I'd had enough. My BS had me go for a breast MRI just in case to further the evidence for my insurance company but with that and the last mammo they approved it right away. I am 47, have had abnormal mammos and biopsies since age 31, and only a paternal grandmother with BC.  I opted not to have genetic testing so insurance can't say my developing BC was a "pre-existing condition" and deny me coverage in the future. I am very happy with my choice.  The PBM, TEs, and exchange were not easy but I think it is more than worth it to remove the worry and constant need for biopsies from my life.
Posts.Title: Prophylactic BLM for ADH? HelloFromCT Daudine

Posts.Content: Apr 2, 2009 12:44PM geysermom wrote: I was so very very glad to see these posts!  I was going along ok thinking I was handling everything reasonably well,  then I would turn so bitchy at the drop of a hat. My BM is scheduled for 4/16.   Also, I have been obsessed with doing research in order to plan for every single thing I may not be able to do post op or buying anything that could possibly help make things easier for me or make me look more "normal" and less like my breasts are gone. Since realizing I am indeed normal and not losing my mind or overreacting, I went to my FP and she prescribed something for sleep.  With better sleep at night, I am much better able to focus instead of obsess and my DH is calmer since I am able to be nicer to him.  He was not complaining before but he has been so very supportive and he didn't deserve the way I was treating him because I was so cranky plus I will definately need him on my side after my surgery!
Posts.Title: OMG-it hit me today-HARD! TCGGal faithandprayers

Posts.Content: geysermom wrote: Since my PS put me on Lyrica and said I was experiencing pain "nerve pain" (severe burning sensations on my lateral chest wall) less than a week after surgery,  I have done a little research on the internet and have found that Lyrica is used for something called Post Mastectomy Syndrome.  Post Mastectomy Syndrome is a chronic pain condition caused by nerve damage that is a result of some mastectomy surgeries.  The sources I found on the internet said this occurs in 10-40% (percentages varied widely depending on the article) of mastectomy surgeries.  No one warned me that chronic pain was a possibility after my BM.  I feel so frustrated that there is a possiblility that this pain may continue.  I have delt with chronic pain in my past (migraines) that improved significantly after my divorce.  I am really NOT eager to deal with chronic pain again.  My DH (second husband and I am very happily married this time) thinks I am "jumping the gun" but I fear ending up requiring narcotics on any sort of regular basis.  If anyone has experienced this, please explain your personal experience and  what worked for you to relieve your pain! Thanks in advance, Julie  Bilateral Prophylactic Mastectomies for Diffuse ADH Dx 12/2007, Stage 0 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Anyone heard of Post Mastectomy Syndrome? geysermom BoobsinaBox

Posts.Content: May 17, 2009 04:41AM geysermom wrote: I think the amount of help you need depends on your overall health preoperatively and how much pain you are having after surgery. I am in good overall health and very active.  I did, however, have more than the usual amount of pain (from what I read here).  My husband was home with me the first two days after surgery (Saturday and Sunday) and then he returned to work.  The things that I needed help doing: 1.  Washing my back and washing my hair.  My DH took me to a salon twice (every other day) before I could wash my hair myself and I would arrange for him to wash my back by doing it before he went to work or after he got home.  *You could arrange to have a friend take you for a shampoo and then wash your back when they brought you home.  You will only be able to sponge bathe so you could have the rest of your body covered up if you are modest.  2.  I sometimes needed help getting dressed.  I could have done it without DH but it was less painful to have him help me with some items. Things I didn't need help doing: 1.  I never needed help getting in and out of the recliner I slept in for several days and when I started sleeping in a bed I was also able to get in and out by myself.  As I mentioned before, I am in reasonably good shape. 2.  I had lots of prepared food from friends and neighbors and I was able to microwave it and carry it to where I was sitting by thinking it through (I couldn't do it in the usual way) and figuring out a way that was not going to hurt or cause me injury. 3.  I managed my drains myself.  However, I have a friend who simply could not bear to look at her drains so she had to have help milking the tubes and emptying the drains.  You probably have some idea of how you will react to having semi-bloody fluid draining out of you and your ability to look at it and/or empty and measure the amount 2-3 times a day. Good luck to you and take care, Julie
Posts.Title: I LIVE ALONE - post bi lat mast help? wabiwoman Jeansbeans

Posts.Content: Apr 30, 2009 01:21AM geysermom wrote: I had BM two weeks ago tomorrow and I agree with Deb and Deeds.  You are so loopy at first (I was nauseated and in so much pain a couple of times that I didn't care that my bottom was on full display in my hospital gown) that you will only want those who are very very close to you around.  I only had DH with me and since my parents don't deal well with any kind of illness,  I was actually relieved when a huge snowstorm prevented them from visiting me in the hospital.  My children live across the country so we encouraged them just to stay where they were and DH and I would let them know about my progress. My parents visited after I went home and other than that only one close neighbor has been allowed to visit since my surgery.  Their visits, although brief, really wore me out. You really need to focus your energy on recovery from your surgery, not towards entertaining your family and friends.  If you feel up to it, you can always call and let them know how you are doing.  That way you can call when you are not loopy from the medication and are feeling relatively well. Good luck with your surgery and try to think postive thoughts, I really believe that makes a difference in making your experience a good one. Julie
Posts.Title: surgery on April 30, 2009 precious1969 geysermom

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2009 07:38PM geysermom wrote: Hi Lewisfamily503, I currently have 5 areas that need to be evaluated with core needle biopsies.  I have had three previous biopsies in the past with the last one showing ADH that was removed by open biopsy.  I am so sick and tired of mammos (always abnormal and requiring f/u) that I have stopped having them at several points in the past.  I realize this is dangerous but it was the only way I could cope while going through a divorce.  My BS is recommending bilateral mastectomies with reconstruction.  I agree with her but feel I may be jumping the gun.  If I require one more open biopsy in the same breast there won't be much left anyway (I am small breasted).  This decision is so difficult to make!  My second husband is very supportive and says he just want me to be alive, breasts or no breasts.  It is good to hear that you have been happy about your decision and I want to feel the same. Thanks, Julie
Posts.Title: Bi-lateral prof mast? runalot08 runalot08

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2009 08:15PM geysermom wrote: You need to wait a bit longer and try to be patient.  My lumpectomy scar was very sunken in the middle which the surgeon said was due to the incision being "stuck" to the tissue below.  It looked pretty bad, but she said to give it some time and if necessary the scar could be revised.  Well, one night I woke up slightly because I felt a "pop" in my chest and in the morning I noticed the scar was no longer stuck to the tissue underneath and was considerably smoother.  Over the next several months it just continued to look better and better.  It is actually barely visable now. Good Luck!
Posts.Title: Scar on breast from lumpectomy Sukiann Spinnerpom
